awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Atmospheres of Young Planets
awd_abstract_narration:
This work is part of a collaborative project to collect direct imaging data of exoplanets and then model the atmospheres.  This work focuses on cool giant planets, which are the type expected to be first detected with these techniques (due to their larger orbital distances from the host star).  They will use data collected from direct imaging surveys to test models of the atmospheres, and include clouds, vertical mixing, non-solar abundances, and non-local chemical equilibrium effects in their calculations. 

This project will also involve public outreach through Lowell Observatory and the American Museum of Natural History, which will develop and present online and in-person programs on the scientific results from direct imaging of planets.  They will also train undergraduate and graduate students in research.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported Prof. Emily Rice (PI) and CUNY physics graduate student Paige Godfrey in conducting spectral analysis of low-mass companions detected with high-contrast imaging instruments and of analog free-floating brown dwarfs. Brown dwarfs are objects that form like stars do, from collapsing clouds of gas and dust, but without enough mass to reach a high enough core temperature to stably generate energy by fusing hydrogen into helium. Thus brown dwarfs cool, shrink, and fade with time. Brown dwarf spectral classes include M, L, T, and Y dwarfs, and they overlap in observational properties as well as in atmospheric and physical properties with young, high-mass exoplanets.

Prof. Rice led a study to determine the accuracy and precision of atmospheric parameters that can be inferred from spectra obtained by high-contrast instruments, using simulated spectra from M, L, and T dwarf templates and synthetic spectra from model atmospheres. That study found that spectra with an average signal to noise ratio of about 10 is sufficient to characterize temperature and gravity as well as possible given the model grid. Most relevant for direct imaging campaigns targeting young primary stars is the finding that low resolution near-infrared spectra of known young objects, compared to field (old) objects of the same spectral type, result in similar best-fit surface gravities but lower effective temperatures, highlighting the need for better observational and theoretical understanding of the entangled effects of temperature, gravity, and dust on near-infrared spectra in cool, low-gravity atmospheres.

The majority of Dr. Godfrey’s thesis project focused on fitting synthetic spectra from cool atmosphere models to the low-resolution near-infrared spectra of T dwarfs, the coolest fully-populated spectral class of brown dwarfs, in order to constrain their physical properties and evaluate model performance as a foundation for interpreting the lower-quality spectra of companions detected by high-contrast imaging instruments.  Dr. Godfrey defended her thesis in April 2017, and two papers from her thesis research are in preparation.

Prof. Rice and Dr. Godfrey also contributed to the analysis of several brown dwarf or planetary-mass companions detected with high contrast instruments Project 1640 or the Gemini Planet Imager.

Intellectual Merit

This work contributes to our scientific understanding of low-mass companions to stars, including brown dwarfs and exoplanets. In using brown dwarfs as analogs to exoplanets, we leverage the copious high-quality data that is available for brown dwarfs in order to reliably and efficiently characterize low-mass companions is necessarily limited, lower-quality data given current observational techniques. This work also lays the foundation for testing companion formation by establishing primary atmospheric properties of temperature and gravity so that future studies may test for differences in metallicity (composition) of companion from their host stars, which would indicate whether they formed like a binary system (similar composition) or star-planet system (companion with a higher metal content).

Broader Impacts

Both the PI and the graduate student were active in education and public outreach during the duration of the grant period. They both taught lecture and/or lab sections of general education introductory astronomy at the CUNY College of Staten Island. Rice and Godfrey also presented numerous talks and participated in events for public outreach, including at the Hayden Planetarium, the American Museum of Natural History, Astronomy on Tap NYC, and various amateur astronomy groups. Dr. Godfrey is now Director of Research with Slooh, LLC, were she remains active in research and public education & outreach.
